# Problem 

<!-- 

*You throw at random* $N$ *disks of radius* $R$ *with* $N \pi R^2 = 1$ *on the unit square. Does the area covered by the disks converge to a limit as* $N$ *gets large? If so, whats the limit?*

-->

Does the area covered by the disks converge to a limit as N gets large? If so, what&#39;s that limit? <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/maths?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#maths</a> <a href="https://t.co/wR9qXnbpjn">pic.twitter.com/wR9qXnbpjn</a></p>&mdash; adad8mðŸ¦ž (@adad8m) <a href="https://twitter.com/adad8m/status/1846034945116196976?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">October 15, 2024</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>

```{r}
library(ggplot2)
set.seed(1)
throw_disk <- \(n = 1, r = sqrt(1 / (pi * n))){
  dplyr::tibble(x = runif(n), y = runif(n), r = r)
}

throw_disk(n = 1e2) |>
  ggplot() + 
  ggforce::geom_circle(aes(x0 = x, y0 = y, r = r), fill = "lightblue", color = "lightblue", alpha = .5) + 
  geom_path(data = dplyr::tibble(x = c(0, 1, 1, 0, 0), y = c(0, 0, 1, 1, 0)), aes(x = x, y = y)) + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_fixed(ratio = 1)
```
